instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.SMC_LID: What is SMC_LID? SMC_LID tells the machine the system is open when it is 3.3v to 3.4v, and closed when it is low such as 0v-0.6v. When this signal is low, the machine may go to sleep or have no backlight. .
definitions.D7701: What is D7701? diode in the backlight circuit sitting between the BKL_SW pin of the LED driver and backlight output. Very common for via between this and BKL_FB for feedback to blow, causing no boost. Measure continuity between pin 2 of this diode and feedback pin of LED driver if backlight output is PPBUS_G3H with no boost.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.BKL_EN: What is BKL_EN? BKL_EN enables backlight. Anytime you see a signal ending with “_EN” , that means this signal being present/high enables what it is referring to. This signal says “BKL” before “_EN”. “BKL” sounds short for “BACKLIGHT”, so it is safe to assume this signal enables backlight when present. .
definitions.BKL_PWM: What is BKL_PWM? BKL_PWM sets the brightness of the screen. The system will send a PWM signal to BKL_PWM pin to set brightness. If this is low, backlight voltage will boost higher than PPBUS_G3H input, but not enough to make the screen light properly..
definitions.BKL_SDA: What is BKL_SDA? BKL_SDA is an SMBUS data line between the LED driver and the system management controller(SMC).
definitions.EDP_BKLT_PWM: What is EDP_BKLT_PWM? EDP_BKLT_PWM sets the brightness of the screen. The system will send a PWM signal to BKL_PWM pin to set brightness. If this is low, backlight voltage will boost higher than PPBUS_G3H input, but not enough to make the screen light properly..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> flickering backlight
threads.message:
Hi!

i have this <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board that has no water damage, but suddenly the backlight started flickering.
I?ve repaired a lot of not working backlights on these machine but never seen before a flickering one.

Where do you suggest to start? 

thanks! :)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> flickering backlight
threads.message: Tried new screen? Inspect LED Driver area for corrosion as well as DC-in board/flex as they control the <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> signal (Hall sensor)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> flickering backlight
threads.message: Probably bad solder at A5 ball of backlight chip; replace it.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> flickering backlight
threads.message:
Found slight water damage under <CHIP>U7701</CHIP>...so i've changed:

<CHIP>U7701</CHIP>
<RESISTOR>R7715</RESISTOR>
<RESISTOR>R7731</RESISTOR>
<RESISTOR>R7714</RESISTOR>
<RESISTOR>R7704</RESISTOR>
<CAPACITOR>C7704</CAPACITOR>
<RESISTOR>R7716</RESISTOR>
<CAPACITOR>C7711</CAPACITOR>

Nothing changed, no backlight!...what can i check now?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> flickering backlight
threads.message:
Did you check XW7720???
You have a sticky post about this problem.
[URL="https://boards.rossmanngroup.com/forum/board-repair-troubleshooting/1145-macbook-air-no-backlight-troubleshooting-guide"]https://boards.rossmanngroup.com/for...shooting-guide[/URL]
Did you really check all the info from the forum?
Hundreds of threads with same issue, even pictures a lot.
[URL="https://boards.rossmanngroup.com/search?q=xw7720&searchJSON=%7B%22keywords%22%3A%22xw7720%22%7D"]https://boards.rossmanngroup.com/sea...22xw7720%22%7D[/URL]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> flickering backlight
threads.message:
Yes, connections on XW7220 are perfect!
Voltages on <DIODE>D7701</DIODE>: 7.7v on both sides

(Yes, i'm trying to use that threads too, thanks!)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> flickering backlight
threads.message:
Did you check continuity to A5 ball?
Any corrosion sign when chip lifted?

Post <SIGNAL>BKL_EN</SIGNAL>/PWM.
Try PRAM reset.

Did you try known good full LCD assembly?
Flickers more on low backlight, or viceversa?

"Voltages on <DIODE>D7701</DIODE>: 7.7v on both sides"
Cannot flickers, should be always black then...

BTW, use only charger; confirm if <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 8.5V aprox.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> flickering backlight
threads.message:
<CHIP>U7701</CHIP>:
12 - <SIGNAL>BKL_FLTR</SIGNAL> 9.8k
3 - <SIGNAL>BKL_EN</SIGNAL> 75k
8 - <SIGNAL>BKL_ISET</SIGNAL> 16k
4 - <SIGNAL>BKL_PWM</SIGNAL> .47
19 - <SIGNAL>BKL_SDA</SIGNAL> 10.5k
9 - <SIGNAL>BKL_FSET</SIGNAL> .19

Yeah, after changing <CHIP>U7701</CHIP> and surrounding components blacklight is always off now.

You mean pin5 of <CHIP>U7701</CHIP>? If yes, under scope is perfectly soldered,
and had no corrosion on pads when chip lifted.
Tried with another know good full lcd assembly.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 8.58V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> flickering backlight
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> flickering backlight
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> flickering backlight
threads.message:
Continuity from <CHIP>U7701</CHIP> A5 ball and pin2 of <DIODE>D7701</DIODE> fine!

Sorry, i was really tired after a lot of non-stop work! 
Here are the voltages:

3 <SIGNAL>BKL_EN</SIGNAL>     2.8v
4 <SIGNAL>BKL_PWM</SIGNAL> 0v
(voltages taken with magsafe, lcd connected)
thanks!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> flickering backlight
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>BKL_PWM</SIGNAL> 0v"
No way to get backlight then.

Post diode mode to grounde for <SIGNAL>BKL_PWM</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>EDP_BKLT_PWM</SIGNAL>.
Check <RESISTOR>R7704</RESISTOR> integrity.
If all good, do PRAM reset few times.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> flickering backlight
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R7704</RESISTOR> looks good, perfectly soldered and has a value of 47ohm.

<SIGNAL>BKL_PWM</SIGNAL> 0.815
<SIGNAL>EDP_BKLT_PWM</SIGNAL> 0.026

tried PRAM reset few times, nothing changes

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> flickering backlight
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>BKL_PWM</SIGNAL> 0.815
<SIGNAL>EDP_BKLT_PWM</SIGNAL> 0.026"
Impossible with 47 ohm resistor in the middle; no matters 33, or 47.
Check again please.

If you really have low value at PCH side, it is probably bad.
Still possible to froce <SIGNAL>BKL_PWM</SIGNAL> high, after <RESISTOR>R7704</RESISTOR> removed.
Detailed instructions in the mentioned threads.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> flickering backlight
threads.message:
Could this be a analog fail? Is the flickering random?

I had a back light that was killing me.  Under the scope the resistors looked ok.  Nice solder blobs present.   But I later discovered that it got under the resistor and released it from the pad even though it looked OK on top!  First time I saw that and it ate my lunch.

Grab a known working board and start comparing resistance and diode checks.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> flickering backlight
threads.message:
I have backlight!
First tried with the jumper method and worked, then resoldered <RESISTOR>R7704</RESISTOR> and now working perfectly.
Pads underneath was perfect by looking at it, but scraping it showed a layer of oxidation.

Thanks a lot guys!
